Interface JPEditPlugin

  • Method Details

    • onPluginLoad

      void onPluginLoad(@NotNull @NotNull List<JPEditWindow> windows) throws Exception
      This method is called exactly once when the plugin is loaded. It is passed a list of all the JPEditWindow instances that currently exist. The class that implements this method is reflectively constructed and this method is called, however before this method is called, the properties returned by pluginProperties() are loaded.

      The pluginProperties() method can return null on which case nothing happens. Any property can also be null. Once all the properties are dealt with this method is called.

      It is appropriate to do and expected that all plugin initialization will take place in this method such as opening or reading files or preferences and creating and starting any workers or threads

      This method can throw any exception if the initialization of a plugin fails A message will be shown to the user indicating your class failed to load and the exception thrown will be written to the error log

      Parameters:
      windows - the list of currently existing JPEditWindows
      Throws:
      Exception - according to implementation if the plugin fails to load
      See Also:
      • PluginProperties
      • pluginProperties()
      • JPEditWindow

    • onNewWindow

      void onNewWindow(@NotNull @NotNull List<JPEditWindow> existingWindows, @NotNull @NotNull JPEditWindow newWindow)
      This method is called on every plugin that is loaded one time whenever, and each time a new JPEditWindow is created.
      Parameters:
      existingWindows - a list of all the JPEditWindows that existed before the creation of the new window
      newWindow - the new JPEditWindow instance that was created

    • onWindowClose

      default void onWindowClose(@NotNull @NotNull List<JPEditWindow> windows, @NotNull @NotNull JPEditWindow closingWindow)
      This method is called on every JPEditPlug that has been loaded each time when a window is destroyed. It gives the plugin the opportunity to address a particular window before it is destroyed without requiring the entire application to quit. The `windows` list may be empty if it is the last window being destroyed.

      The closingWindow is not hidden or closed until *after* this method is called on it. It is still visible when this method is called on it

      Because this method was introduced long after the initial API, it is a default method that by default takes no action. Existing plugins and new ones can take advantage of this method if they'd like.

      Parameters:
      windows - currently all the windows that are open and staying open (might be empty)
      closingWindow - the window that is being destroyed

    • pluginProperties

      @Nullable @Nullable PluginProperties pluginProperties()
      This method is called to retrieve an instance of PluginProperties that describes the properties of this plugin. This method may return null.

      If you are using the PluginProperties method then it is important that each JPEditWindow gets a new instance of PluginKeyboardShortcut, PluginMenuItem, and PluginToolbarButton. Any sharing between instances will deprive all but one of the windows that are sharing from being able to use the items.

      The best way to accomplish this uniqueness is to construct each object inside this method so that each time it is called a new PluginMenuItem, PluginToolbarButton, etc. are created. This method is called once for each existing window when the plugin loads and once again on every plugin when a new window is created. Caching PluginProperties object to return every time will not work as multiple windows cannot have the same instances of these objects.

      If you provide a pluginProperties, the program will take care of loading the button, MenuItem, and keyboard shortcuts on every window when the plugin loads and on every subsequent created window while the plugin is loaded. You should not write the code to add these things into the window in any of your implemented methods. This will be taken care of by the program

      Returns:
      the PluginProperties object representing the properties of this plugin or null if no properties exist
      See Also:
      • PluginProperties

    • onRemoved

      default void onRemoved(List<JPEditWindow> windows)
      This method is called on the plugin when the user opts to remove it, but the application is not closing. This is called on the plugin before the buttons, shortcuts, and menu items are removed from the program.

      after this method completes the objects in pluginProperties() are removed from the program.

      By default this method calls onExit() to allow for backwards-compatibility with existing plugins. The onExit behavior is most similar to this method. The default assuption is that whatever the plugin would do on exit of the program is approximately what it should do here, but the method can be implemented to customize this.

      It should be noted that the program will take of calling unregister methods and removing the various items included in PluginProperties. This method and the plugin itself should not attempt to manipulate the ApplicationContext or individual windows during this method. It is best to save whatever user data is needed and return from the method.

      Parameters:
      windows - the list of currently open windows

    • onExit

      void onExit()
      This method is called exactly once on every plugin when JPEditWindow is about to quit and after every existing JPEditWindow has been closed

      This method should do all the necessary tearing down and de-initialization of the plugin such as saving files or settings and ending workers or threads.
